abstract: In the more aggressive antitrust climate of the Obama administration, the stakes appear to be highest for Google.
snippet: In the more aggressive antitrust climate of the Obama administration, the stakes appear to be highest for Google.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the nation’s biggest antitrust cases have centered on technology companies. And they have all been efforts by the government to deal with powerful companies with far-reaching influence, like AT&T, the telephone monopoly; I.B.M., the mainframe computer giant; and Microsoft, the powerhouse of personal computer software.

headline.main: New Mood in Antitrust May Target Google
headline.print_headline: New Mood In Antitrust May Affect Google

byline.original: By Steve Lohr and Miguel Helft

abstract: The Palm Pre, an updated iPhone and new phones using the Android operating system are arriving this summer.
snippet: The Palm Pre, an updated iPhone and new phones using the Android operating system are arriving this summer.
lead_paragraph: The hype machine started months ago. Opening weekends are upon us. High up in executive suites, the hope is that this summer’s new releases will cause lines to snake around the block.

headline.main: Cellphone Makers Hope for a Blockbuster Summer

abstract: As the Obama administration gears up to toughen antitrust enforcement, the stakes appear to be highest for Google, the rising power of the Internet economy.
snippet: As the Obama administration gears up to toughen antitrust enforcement, the stakes appear to be highest for Google, the rising power of the Internet economy.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Obama administration declared a sharp break with the Bush years, vowing to toughen antitrust enforcement, especially for dominant companies. The approach is closer to that of the European Union, where regulators last week fined Intel $1.45 billion for abusing its power in the chip market.

headline.main: New Mood in Antitrust May Target Google
